body:
I've marked the PR as a preview to have a discussion on this. There are a few test and test data to be fixed according to the outcome of this discussion.

Would it make sense to add coloring to the import statements?

To me it also would make sense to have the `@` as normal separator and use the semantic highlighter to change that color when used together with an annotation type otherwise `@interface` might look odd. I do not know. Let's talk about this!
@mbien The preview use the lexer only. I'm testing if I can add a highlighter there as well, that would come in a separate PR, if I can make that happen.

This is issue is still present in version 19. What is the point of keeping a button on the GUI that does absolutely nothing?  Please can it be removed??  Or maybe follow the H2G2 example and flash up a message that says "Please do not press this button again"  ;-)
And are you aware that the menu Help > Report Issue takes you to a 404 page?  As Arthur Dent might have said: This is obviously some strange usage of the word 'help' that I wasn't previously aware of.
This is great - ty @sroeper - wondering if Terminal is having a similar issue. Can't seem to get to work on M1 but it works fine on Intel. Have you - or anyone else - seen the same?

> This is great - ty @sroeper - wondering if Terminal is having a similar issue. Can't seem to get to work on M1 but it works fine on Intel. Have you - or anyone else - seen the same?

Yeah, terminal does not work for me as well. It used to work though.
I just downloaded 20-rc3 (binary zip) and Terminal works on my M1. So hoping when the `pkg` installer is released with v20  it will be fixed.
adding https://github.com/apache/netbeans/labels/Contribution%20welcome for @bobl01

> Would it make sense to add coloring to the import statements?

you mean the fully qualified type behind `import`?
```java
import java.util.ArrayList;
//     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ this?
```
not sure. To me it is probably not necessary, since it should probably have the same color as:
```java
list = new java.util.ArrayList<>();
//         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ <- essentially the same thing
```
Or do you mean something else?

There are two separate questions to ask I think: what should the editor offer and which part should be used in the default theme.
It could be nice to have an option to customize import statements but maybe it shouldn't be enabled by default. Although I think it would probably look nice to reduce saturation for the imports on some themes which have the contrast budget for that since those code areas are generally less import-ant :)

e.g I am experimenting with a higher contrast theme based on flatlaf dark which would probably have the contrast budget to tone imports down a bit:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/2223703e-5094-466e-b72b-645b9fb2aa59)

1.  Yes, I mean the FQN after the import. Right now if you start use different colors by element kind it would look like this:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1381701/0adbce10-18f4-4c31-a5b9-8b2e410cf651)

2. I have not really thought about the colors, defaults yet, other than I wish to put some emphasis/distinction on annotations.
I guess someone who can do it, would change the preview to see the parser, and if it can be done, then preview could be free to accept any user text much like the main editor.

> I guess someone who can do it

Well, that could be a problem..

> I guess someone who can do it, would change the preview to see the parser, and if it can be done, then preview could be free to accept any user text much like the main editor.

Well we may not need a preview version at all, we could just open a "tab" inside that preview window.

took another look and I agree that this should be fine. `InstantContent.add/remove` modify a list without any synchronization. The lookup (which is synchronized) is later used on EDT, so manipulating `InstantContent` on EDT is the right thing to do... and it is fixing the race too.

thanks for the review -> merging
I interpret the thumbs up as go ahead with merge :)
What was the reason to close it @PavelTurk? Did you find a solution, if yes, what is the solution to let everyone knows.

@Chris2011 Thank you for you comment. Right click on project -> Reload helped me once. But I am not sure that this is a valid solution for serious cases. For now I decided to close this issue and wait till next problem.

@PavelTurk The "spec" or IMHO proposal is very old and that were just ideas when I see the comments. They also provide alternatives to keep them separated inside tht test folder. How often do you see this structure, that you recommend in the wild, how often do you have exact this structure that "breaks" the behaviour of NetBeans, due to you can't see the tests inside the Project tab?
@tmysik Could you please have a look at each commit when you have time?

I was thinking of this for a bit, and also asked someone associated with the JEP (seems it was meant so that we highlighting the embedded expressions as expressions - which we do, and also the braces in a different way, which we don't). I think I would like to try with this as it is, and see how that works. We can adjust if/as needed. Please let me know if there are any objections. Thanks!

@lahodaj all good! It was just me reading the JEP wrong. I do actually like how it looks at the moment (as mentioned before). Thanks for asking your colleagues for clarification.

The default NB theme doesn't even distinguish char from string literals (which is fine) since the difference rarely matters:

![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/1f451419-0a48-4d32-9037-a59207343b9f)


> seems it was meant so that (...), and also the braces in a different way, which we don't

highlighting `\{` is probably easy since `\` is an escape character so it could use existing code which highlights `\n` etc, finding the matching bracket would require new logic most likely. Btw I fixed a small bug in ml string brace matching: #6726

I can't reproduce this unfortunately. I have now central2 and central3 in settings.xml and central4 and central5 in two separate projects the project poms all pointing to the same url and it is only downloading one index. Were the IDs **and** the URLs different in your case? (since this is the only scenario where I could make it download it twice).

You can monitor in real-time which repositories NB is aware of by looking at the services window.

I am also not sure I agree with the conclusion. The same repository can have multiple URLs, as is the case for central for example, so this wouldn't help.

Permissions are per-URL, index storage and identification is per ID.

If a pom makes up a new ID, that ID becomes a new repo from maven POV (although NB seems to be already doing some url and ID based deduplication too I noticed during testing). (not to mention that it goes against best practice to set the repo in the project pom - it is set by the environment - setting it to central is also pointless since it is already set by the superpom)

It seems it won't download multiple at the same time, but it does prepare the directories. Downloading takes ages, so testing is a bit slow... :)

```
~/.cache/netbeans/19/mavenindex $ du -sh *
3.3G	central
6.3G	central2
6.3G	central3
54M	local
36K 	Maven Central
39M	osgeo
20K 	ossrh
```
After a bit more testing, it seems Netbeans only de-duplicates repositories with the same URL _that are currently open_. Close all projects, open a one that has the same repo with a different id and netbeans will start re-downloading.

I suspect "central" is the default one (repo.maven.apache.org) while the other three are repo1.maven.org. Is there a way to see which URL belongs to those caches?

The different urls for the same repo are a tricky one. But that mainly seems to be the case for central. Maybe a way to register aliases for a repo? That having repos in the pom goes against best practices may be true, but that doesn't help in the real world when having to deal with external projects...

I noticed the editor also won't acknowledge new files if there is any project or profiler running (Dont even has to be the same project im editing), but as soon as I close everything it triggers a "background scanning" and the changes update.
The profiler is likely pausing IO to not influence the measurements. This issue here is something else and specific to java modules.

@tmysik Fixed : https://github.com/apache/netbeans/compare/e53b9278c63011edf23dc592d66827e77d98edbe..7e705639b19ce57a0fe0984cdc8e91ac2f4272bc

Thank you for your review and your time :)
@junichi11 Nothing to thank for, really. NetBeans users have to thank you, Junichi. Without you, there would not be any up-to-date PHP support in NetBeans at all! üëç

> After a bit more testing, it seems Netbeans only de-duplicates repositories with the same URL that are currently open

If you don't have any repositories defined, all NB sees are transient repositories taken from the context of your projects and maven defaults, which means deduplication will quit working once there are no duplicates. If you add a repo with right URL manually to the services window, or to .m2/settings.xml it should continue working even if you close projects.

I think we can solve this by automatically adding the remote repository, once fully indexed, to the services view. I tested this and it seems to work fine.

> The different urls for the same repo are a tricky one. But that mainly seems to be the case for central. Maybe a way to register aliases for a repo?

I also added a mapping to convert the repo1 url to apache.org for transient repositories. I want to get other PRs in first, once done, I will post a link to a dev build here.

> That having repos in the pom goes against best practices may be true, but that doesn't help in the real world when having to deal with external projects...

NB is still an IDE. It does what devs tell it to do if the projects are trusted. Adding magic can be bad - if it starts to swap out URLs and ignore repos it could stop being a useful tool once the behavior is no longer predictable.

Automatically adding central should fix the disk space issue, most other repositories will be tiny in comparison. Might it be something for the janitor to occasionally check, if there are large mavenindex caches that have not been used in a while?

Thank you for looking into it.

@Chris2011 We can look at it this way - `src/it` is not so popular because not many IDE support it :) . But if we speak seriously two statements are important 1) unit test and it test can differ very much in time execution, code coverage, required environment etc. 2) it is better so keep different things separately.

It looks the Windows clipboard is not available at a given time from Netbeans.
The workaround described as double CTRL+C on empty text do not work all the times... I would say rarely.
Anyway I was able to understand how it is restored the correct behaviour (even if for very short time).
CRTL+Shift+D will access the Netbeans clipboard popup, after you just need to paste one fo the presented items and magically the Windows clipboard will be accessible again... of course all of this is time consuming.
To be noted that the Netbeans cliboard popup do not show as last item the last copy we did from Windows, so the bug seems to be that the Netbeans clipboard is not always listening for Windows events.
And what is the problem of having it like `src/test/it` and everything else has a differenz folder as they suggested it in the metioned links from you?

> Automatically adding central should fix the disk space issue

it has to work dynamically, since there are also mirrors, e.g: https://storage-download.googleapis.com/maven-central/index.html
Organizations might also have internal mirrors of central.

> Might it be something for the janitor to occasionally check

it would notice abandoned cache dirs, so assuming someone updates to a new NB version from time to time, the old ones would be automatically removed: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/4900 

Maybe this isn't aggressive enough, but I think if we mitigate the duplicates issue a bit, this might be less of a problem for most since there wouldn't be duplicates in the first place.
@Chris2011 With `src/it` you can create another JPMS module with its own dependencies, services etc. So, in one maven project you can have three JPMS modules: `src/main`, `src/test`, `src/it`.
@ebarboni can you take a quick look at this, would like to merge since I have something else pending. This includes a change in a sig file too.

+1 sorry I was puzzled as I found outdated constants but it's defined https://github.com/apache/maven
 DEFAULT_REMOTE_REPO_URL with the apache url.

> It looks the Windows clipboard is not available at a given time from Netbeans. The workaround described as double CTRL+C on empty text do not work all the times... I would say rarely. Anyway I was able to understand how it is restored the correct behaviour (even if for very short time). CRTL+Shift+D will access the Netbeans clipboard popup, after you just need to paste one fo the presented items and magically the Windows clipboard will be accessible again... of course all of this is time consuming. To be noted that the Netbeans cliboard popup do not show as last item the last copy we did from Windows, so the bug seems to be that the Netbeans clipboard is not always listening for Windows events.

Copying text from about windows usually fixes it for me 
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/7459881/87ff9cb1-aaef-4bbe-874f-71ac8eae68e7)

proposed PR is linked above, the CI workflow produces a dev-build for testing, e.g:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/7020247076?pr=6757 scroll to bottom of the page

please check if this fixes your issue. This would target NB 21 so there is time.

Tested on Intel Mac and all is fine - Test Results window pops open and is populated with test results.

Tested on a Mac with Apple silicone... and I get a blank Test Results window (have to manually open it).

Maybe another issue with native build like with the profiler.
PS: The slowness seems to be present on version 19 (JDK 21) and 18 (JDK 17) but I have not tested an older version.
Some quick tests show that the fix seems to work, but I'll test further in the future. Thanks for the fix!
Good. So from this decision and fix rejection, it took almost 5 weeks to reach a votable distribution.
@sdedic seriously?! Maybe you could have a private word with @MartinBalin about the real reasons this release has been delayed rather than pulling this toxic crap on here!

and now imagine how long it would take if we would integrate non trivial PRs after delivery branched!

Check the RC release notes if you want and list a PR with similar risks for side effects as the reverted PR.

Lets try to get a release with fewer RCs next time while integrating as many PRs as possible, help is always welcome - release managers are doing this in their free time.

And please stop with the passive aggressive tone and lets stay professional, if you would have followed the repeated offer to talk to us, you would know why there were delays! I am not even in the release team and am aware of it.

And I think I just solved it while gathering info for the bug report.

The version I'm running is x86_64, so it is running under emulation. After digging around, we were provided with the [Codelerity / Gj IT packages](https://www.codelerity.com/netbeans/) installation package for x86_64, instead of the Apache-provided PKG file.

After installing the PKG file version, it is reporting it is running under arm64, and the visual lag is gone.

Well; one one hand, one is told not to destabilize `delivery` - understandable. And a reminder - I did not say a word about or against discarding those PRs from the NB20 release (well, except delaying a fix for gradle, for the same reason as these PRs were reverted). On the other hand, one is reminded not to diverge `master` too much, which is ALSO understandable bcs of the delivery merging. So I naturally waited.

For these fixes, the delay is 5 weeks - since I did not reintegrated  #6514 to `master`, so 5 weeks less testing. Should I fix that now ? Is the remaining time till Jan 15 sufficient for testing acceptance ?
With this PR now, I believe merge to `master` and let it be.
@lkishalmi do the changes look sane ? I'd merge it in the following days

> Is the remaining time till Jan 15 sufficient for testing acceptance ?

if you merge something you should be available to stabilize the change as committer. Its just like in any other project. You don't commit something and leave for vacation. So if you and the reviewers think the time is sufficient then absolutely, lets get the revisited priming change reviewed (including the fix) and merged. Worst case is that someone reverts something again if there is no time left to fix it properly.

fyi: I chatted on apache slack with maven devs and the google mirrors linked above are the only known public mirrors atm. So its realistically just about a handful of URLs where maven central can be. But any org can run their own repo of course.

please ignore the lock/unlock. This is our trick to force a new workflow run which takes new labels into account for the jobs. Since you can't label things, someone else has to do that :) (not sure if VSCode tests should run there too, a reviewer will know)

I tested with a fresh user config and a plain maven project and the wizard (using remote xsd file) seems to require the EE cluster to be enabled, otherwise pressing finish won't do anything. It will log this exception quietly:
```
java.io.IOException: JAXB compiler is not available for this project.
	at org.netbeans.modules.xml.jaxb.ui.JAXBWizardIterator.instantiate(JAXBWizardIterator.java:160)
	at org.openide.loaders.TemplateWizard.handleInstantiate(TemplateWizard.java:602)
	at org.openide.loaders.TemplateWizard.instantiateNewObjects(TemplateWizard.java:436)
	at org.openide.loaders.TemplateWizardIterImpl.instantiate(TemplateWizardIterImpl.java:223)
	at org.openide.loaders.TemplateWizardIteratorWrapper.instantiate(TemplateWizardIteratorWrapper.java:135)
	at org.openide.WizardDescriptor.callInstantiateOpen(WizardDescriptor.java:1605)
	at org.openide.WizardDescriptor.callInstantiate(WizardDescriptor.java:1546)
	at org.openide.WizardDescriptor.access$2300(WizardDescriptor.java:67)
[catch] at org.openide.WizardDescriptor$Listener$2$1.run(WizardDescriptor.java:2233)
	at org.openide.util.RequestProcessor$Task.run(RequestProcessor.java:1420)
	at org.netbeans.modules.openide.util.GlobalLookup.execute(GlobalLookup.java:45)
	at org.openide.util.lookup.Lookups.executeWith(Lookups.java:287)
	at org.openide.util.RequestProcessor$Processor.run(RequestProcessor.java:2035)
```
might be some ergonomics issue?

edit: worked fine post manual activation
edit2: NB doesn't seem to have xsd file templates. It was likely part with the visual XML modules which were never donated (forgot the actual name of the feature, but it could visualize xsds etc).
Thank you very much
@mbien I am writing to inform you here that I am still working on it, and as I am a beginner to open source it is taking me time to explore and understand the system

interesting. I put the mac label on it since I can't reproduce this on linux. Clicking new-group closes the dialog and opens the create-group dialog, the (modal) window is in front of the main window for me.

oh, found the problem: 

 - enable window decorations (off on linux by default)
 - get to the create-group dialog
 - now click on the main window

-> dialog is gone and you can't get it easily back, which is weird, since the dialog is supposed to be modal too, which it isn't when window decorations are on

Hmmm, windows decorations option isn't usable (disabled) on the macOS version (under the FlatLaf configuration). I quickly switched to "Mac OS X" LnF to see if it made a difference, but same behaviour.
FWIW, I like how it looks currently as well.

found 
```java
System.setProperty("javax.net.debug", "ssl:handshake");
```
to be useful for SSL debugging. But it produces a lot of output with is mixed with the test output which is also a lot. Would be interesting to diff the two https handshake logs of the gradle `Downloader` with and without the workaround.

exception snippet taken from the PR:
```
Caused by: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Received fatal alert: handshake_failure
	at java.base/sun.security.ssl.Alert.createSSLException(Alert.java:131)
	at java.base/sun.security.ssl.Alert.createSSLException(Alert.java:117)
	at java.base/sun.security.ssl.TransportContext.fatal(TransportContext.java:347)
	at java.base/sun.security.ssl.Alert$AlertConsumer.consume(Alert.java:293)
	at java.base/sun.security.ssl.TransportContext.dispatch(TransportContext.java:186)
	at java.base/sun.security.ssl.SSLTransport.decode(SSLTransport.java:172)

	at java.base/sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.readHandshakeRecord(SSLSocketImpl.java:1421)
```

Thanks for testing. This behavior is not new (reproducible on NB19) and in review kind of expected. The maven schema compiler module is provided by `maven.jaxws`, which is part of the enterprise cluster. The module also actually uses the java ee modules and thus can't be moved to java cluster (where the caller is located).

I think its a race condition. The first dialog disposes the moment the second appears which means the second dialog sometimes doesn't have the main window as parent, but a window which just closed - thats when the UI breaks as soon the main window is focused again.

this workflow will create a dev build: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/7054584808?pr=6772
would be good if you could check if it fixes it for you. 

its working for me on linux, the window decorations seemed to make it easier to reproduce it for me. Tested with JDK 21.0.1 + X11.
Incorrect access rights to the user's cache directory. ~/Library/Caches/NetBeans owned by root not by user. All works fine after correction.
Good sleuthing...that seems to have solved the issue on my platform (same as original post).
This is fixed by htacces changes

I already have a plugin for this feature which is open source (originally implemented by @AlexanderYastrebov), maybe the code helps to implement this feature: https://github.com/funfried/nb-editor-close-left-right

Edit: Just saw @mbien already put a link to the plugin catalogue page of the plugin
@nmatt thanks for reporting btw. You caught that a few h after the redirect failed :)

Is there anything that we (end-users) can do to help debug this issue? I'm a long time user of Netbeans and haven't had any problems like this until a few weeks ago when I had to update my Netbeans install for use with JDK 17-21. I've been running into this issue almost daily. It's incredibly frustrating. I'm more than happy to chip in any way I can.

I finally found the reason for this malfunction. It looks that for security reasons and during a past update Windows 10 has disabled the clipboard history.
It is in my opinion a crazy change also without a clear information to users... by the way we can restore the "classic" clipboard behaviour by tuning the switch available on the System settings under the Clipboard menu on the left.
I attach a screenshot, but please forgive me if I pasted the Italian version, so please read the term "appunti" as "clipboard".
![clipboard-history-is-back](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/29631792/8c075f9a-4fd8-47d8-ac68-21de7933252e)

> I finally found the reason for this malfunction. It looks that for security reasons and during a past update Windows 10 has disabled the clipboard history. It is in my opinion a crazy change also without a clear information to users... by the way we can restore the "classic" clipboard behaviour by tuning the switch available on the System settings under the Clipboard menu on the left. I attach a screenshot, but please forgive me if I pasted the Italian version, so please read the term "appunti" as "clipboard". ![clipboard-history-is-back](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/29631792/287325406-8c075f9a-4fd8-47d8-ac68-21de7933252e.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..yak-mQwm6E87Y1ALhJGlpvb40uVqK3DkbsqwsWUvvpc)

It is on in my PC (For a long time) and the error still happens
Me to, I have win 11 and enabled clipboard history for very long time and the problem in NB 18, 19 still happens

As vote passed I will merge this one.

No conflict seems ok to merge

I asked on the apache slack maven channel about an updated list of public mirrors which caused a little discussion between maven devs and also central maintainers. This lead to an update of the meta xml, which is now listing the remaining public mirrors correctly:
https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/.meta/repository-metadata.xml

So we could collect the mirror info from the repo xml, but since its just 3 urls it is probably ok to keep them hardcoded for now without over engineering it.
thanks a lot for verifying
I have renamed hudson to jenkins for the frontend should I be also renaming the directories, files and as well as the method names?
I can confirm that this is also broken in v20 - macOS w/ Apple silicone.

this is most likely covered by existing maven/gradle reporting plugins.

We also don't really track plugin requests on the NetBeans issue tracker -> closing.
i have no clue what that means
@mbien I find your position very strange.

> Where exactly is this log file?

you can see the log by opening `View -> IDE log`, on top of that log file you also see the value for `User Directory`, thats where the log files are.

Regarding exceptions in javac, we would need minimal reproducers for that. We have to figure out what is causing it and then likely report or fix it upstream in OpenJDK.

closing this issue since we track duplicates already: #5508 or #3725

Well, AFAIK Jenkins is still using some of old package names containing `hudson` in their name. Since we are providing some API as well on hudson naming, probably should leave that as it is.

Renaming the UI elements and replace the the Hudson artwork to Jenkins artwork would be welcome.

As of the module folders, I don't know. I'd probably leave those as they are.

what is the point of providing a hudson API? We won't test it with hudson anymore so it essentially already is API for jenkins. The modules which use the old namespace are on maven central for anyone who would still depend on them.

It would be a false promise to keep using the hudson namespace while serving jenkins users since it will likely break old hudson apps anyway at some point.

lets take a look:
`ide/hudson/nbproject/project.xml` and
`ide/hudson.ui/nbproject/project.xml` exposes API only to friends (as far as I see, please double check)
`ide/hudson.tasklist/nbproject/project.xml` and
`php/hudson.php/nbproject/project.xml`and
`ide/hudson.git/nbproject/project.xml` have no public API

Well, I'm not really serious about backward compatibility and against folder/package renaming.

There is a thing though:
```xml
<friend>oracle.jdevimpl.nbteam.ide</friend>
```

That's out of our realm. I do not know if that is still used or not though...

> <friend>oracle.jdevimpl.nbteam.ide</friend>

we could try to ask someone. The linux kernel does the same. They sometimes ask before removing drivers of esoteric devices which likely nobody uses anymore.

The stackrace points to the X3D plugin:

```
at org.web3d.x3d.config.X3DEditKeyStoreProvider.getKeyStore(X3DEditKeyStoreProvider.java:70)
```

I had a quick look at the plugin and it seems they decided to manipulate system properties to hold their own keystore. This fails.

I think we should learn from the disaster Oracle and the Eclipse Foundation produced. We will see many years where the split between the `jakarta.*` and `javax.*` packages will hurt. And it will serve as a reminder that renaming technical identifiers (packages, classes, ...) will in many cases just create noise. It is not that uncommon in the NetBeans code base not to follow marking BS: Many modules are still called `j2ee*` and several modules support JavaEE and JakartaEE.

That said: If there are people willing to do this work and audit and review, fine with me.
Can a nb21 module be copied into nb20 install, is the API compatible/standardized?

@mbien: This still produces a 404 for me.

Edit: This seems to be a caching issue. Some caches return 404, some serve the working page (requests done from different hosts/networks & browsers):

```
HTTP/2` 404 Not Found
server: Apache
content-type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1
content-encoding: gzip
via: 1.1 varnish, 1.1 varnish
accept-ranges: bytes
date: Sun, 03 Dec 2023 15:58:40 GMT
age: 408
x-served-by: cache-hel1410031-HEL, cache-fra-etou8220044-FRA   <‚Äî‚Äî
x-cache: MISS, HIT
x-cache-hits: 0, 7
```

@nmatt yeah I have a similar issue, when I open it with firefox (which is my regular browser) i see 404 but when I open it with a fresh user session in chrome it works fine.

Lets wait a little bit, maybe it fixes itself, otherwise we have to investigate what is causing this. The redirect is in place as you can see in the linked issue.

edit: if i open the link in Firefox private mode, it does also always work
edit2: opening the same link from a fresh Firefox user config in virtualbox from the same host does also work -> it is likely that browsers cache redirects for a long time and do not check if it changed.

we can start with the frontent first, and if there is still interest do the full renaming in a second step. Both steps are independent anyway

regarding jakarta/javax: I think the difference here is that Hudson was discontinued in 2017, including website and any other form of support. While with jakarta/javax we have the situation that servers still exist to this day which support both runtimes - this leads to the situation that tools do have to support both of them still.

With hudson/jenkins there is now only jenkins to support and as already mentioned we don't expose the API to many "friends", so there is the chance that we could check if it is still used anywhere outside of NB itself.

> This error is in int programs and when press shif +alt+ f

What are `int programs`?

What project type is this, maven/gradle/ant/something else? 

What file type do you have open which you try to format? XML?

Can you post the full log file so that we can see what modules are enabled? (I have the suspicion that the enterprise cluster is disabled)

right, its not a regression. Its just that having no user feedback (not even an exception dialog) after pressing finish isn't ideal.

Maybe we should use `Exceptions.printStackTrace()` for now and update the message slightly to inform the user that enabling a cluster might help?

From NetBeans 18, the only clipboard problem I have on Windows is occasionally failing to paste text from an external app and into NetBeans. In every case, I can reset the broken state by copying something from NetBeans.

yes we all have this problem(from external app), and this kind of reset is strange and not working every time, I must some time copy empty place and the paste for 2,3 times and then maybe it works, this kind of reset is not a option for IDE

I don't use windows but here is how I would attempt to narrow down the issue (assuming I am affected - since not all window users are as seen in this thread):

I would build NB from master on windows, then open the module in question with NB 20, start it with the debugger attached and start my work day in that dev build session of NetBeans. When it happens I would set the break point and check what is going on there.

I would also keep some external clipboard monitoring tools prepared which might help in the investigation.

However, there is the chance that it doesn't happen during debugging sessions due to the fact that this has the symptoms of a race condition - but who knows.
